title: Viewfinder: Buttonwood Farm
text:
Photos by Michele McDonald for The Boston Globe
Brett Kelly (left) and his brother Bruce work as a team
By Michele McDonald Globe correspondent August 02, 2015
T housands of sunflowers bloom in July at Buttonwood Farm in Griswold, Conn., a sight that astonishes and delights. They are grown as part of the Sunflowers for Wishes fund-raiser held by the Button family of Buttonwood Farm. The flowers are picked and packed by volunteers, who show up when the sun rises and work until the farmstand is open for business. All the money from sunflower sales, held over 10 days in July, is donated to the Make-A-Wish Foundation of Connecticut to help children with life-threatening illnesses get a wish fulfilled. In 12 years, the Buttons have raised more than $1 million for the charity.
Brett Kelly (left) and his brother Bruce work as a team. They are just two of the many volunteers who help grant those childrenâ€™s wishes.
Volunteer Amanda Fisher checked the look of a bunch she was getting ready for sale.
Ron Withrow, with his son Max, 11, of Gales Ferry, Conn., stopped to appreciate a sunflower.
This year, the total amount raised for the Make-A-Wish Foundation of Connecticut since 2004 from Buttonwood Farm fundraisers, passed $1 million.
Patrick McGrath, 6, of North Guilford, Conn., was a happy customer.
Volunteers start working in the fields shortly after 6 a.m..
